title: James McDivitt
text:
James Alton McDivitt (born June 10, 1929) is an American former <a href="test%20pilot">test pilot</a>, <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">United States Air Force</a> (USAF) <a href="Aviator">pilot</a>, <a href="aeronautical%20engineer">aeronautical engineer</a>, and <a href="NASA">NASA</a> <a href="astronaut">astronaut</a> who flew in the <a href="Project%20Gemini">Gemini</a> and <a href="Apollo%20program">Apollo program</a>s. He joined the USAF in 1951 and flew 145 <a href="aerial%20warfare">combat missions</a> in the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>. In 1959 he qualified as a test pilot at the <a href="U.S.%20Air%20Force%20Test%20Pilot%20School">Air Force Experimental Flight Test Pilot School</a> (Class 59C) and <a href="Aerospace%20Research%20Pilot%20School">Aerospace Research Pilot School</a> (Class I), and joined the Manned Spacecraft Operations Branch. By September 1962, McDivitt had logged over 2,500 flight hours, of which more than 2,000 hours was in <a href="jet%20aircraft">jet aircraft</a>. This included flying as a <a href="Chase%20plane">chase pilot</a> for <a href="Robert%20M.%20White">Robert M. White</a>'s <a href="North%20American%20X-15">North American X-15</a> flight on July 17, 1962, in which White reached an altitude of and became the first X-15 pilot to be awarded <a href="Astronaut%20Wings">Astronaut Wings</a>.
In 1962, McDivitt was selected as an astronaut by NASA with <a href="Astronaut%20Group%202">Astronaut Group 2</a>. He commanded the <a href="Gemini%204">Gemini 4</a> mission during which <a href="Ed%20White%20%28astronaut%29">Ed White</a> performed the first U.S. <a href="extravehicular%20activity">spacewalk</a>, and later the <a href="Apollo%209">Apollo 9</a> flight which was the first crewed flight test of the <a href="Apollo%20Lunar%20Module">Apollo Lunar Module</a> and the complete set of Apollo flight hardware. He later became Manager of Lunar Landing Operations and was the Apollo Spacecraft Program Manager from 1969 to 1972. In June 1972 he left NASA and retired from the USAF with the rank <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a>.
Early life.
McDivitt was born on June 10, 1929, in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>. He was a <a href="Scouts%20BSA%20%28Boy%20Scouts%20of%20America%29">Boy Scout</a> and earned the rank of <a href="Tenderfoot%20Scout">tenderfoot</a>. He grew up in <a href="Kalamazoo%2C%20Michigan">Kalamazoo, Michigan</a>, where he graduated from <a href="Kalamazoo%20Central%20High%20School">Kalamazoo Central High School</a> in 1947. He then worked for a year to earn enough money to attend <a href="junior%20college">junior college</a>. He completed two years at Jackson Junior College (now known as <a href="Jackson%20College">Jackson College</a>) in <a href="Jackson%2C%20Michigan">Jackson, Michigan</a>, from 1948 to 1950. 
Military service.
In January 1951, McDivitt joined the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">United States Air Force</a> (USAF). The <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a> had commenced, and his deferment from the <a href="Conscription%20in%20the%20United%20States">draft</a> expired when he graduated from Jackson Junior College. Rather than wait and be drafted by the Army, he elected to enlist in the USAF as a <a href="Private%20%28rank%29%23United%20States">private</a>, and applied for pilot training under the <a href="Aviation%20Cadet%20Training%20Program%20%28USAAF%29%23Aviation%20Cadet%20Training%20%28USAF%29%2C%201947%20-%201961/1965">aviation cadet training program</a>. He performed well in training, and was the first in his class to make a <a href="first%20solo%20flight">solo flight</a>. He received his <a href="U.S.%20Air%20Force%20aeronautical%20rating">pilot wings</a> and regular commission as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the USAF in May 1952 at <a href="Williams%20Air%20Force%20Base">Williams Air Force Base</a>, <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, and completed combat crew training in November 1952. He flew 145 <a href="aerial%20warfare">combat missions</a> in Korea in <a href="F-80%20Shooting%20Star">F-80 Shooting Star</a>s and <a href="F-86%20Sabre">F-86 Sabre</a>s with the <a href="35th%20Fighter-Bomber%20Squadron">35th Fighter-Bomber Squadron</a>, and earned two <a href="Distinguished%20Flying%20Cross%20%28United%20States%29">Distinguished Flying Crosses</a>. His last mission was flown two hours after the <a href="Korean%20Armistice%20Agreement">Korean Armistice Agreement</a> was signed.
McDivitt returned to the United States in September 1953 and served as pilot and assistant operations officer with the 19th Fighter Interceptor Squadron at <a href="Dow%20Air%20Force%20Base">Dow Air Force Base</a>, <a href="Maine">Maine</a>. In November 1954, he entered advanced flying school at <a href="Tyndall%20Air%20Force%20Base">Tyndall Air Force Base</a>, <a href="Florida">Florida</a>, and in July 1955 went to <a href="McGuire%20Air%20Force%20Base">McGuire Air Force Base</a>, <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>, where he served as pilot, operations officer, and later as flight commander with the <a href="332d%20Fighter-Interceptor%20Squadron">332d Fighter Interceptor Squadron</a>. In June 1957 he entered the University of Michigan under the <a href="Air%20Force%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Air Force Institute of Technology</a> program, and received his <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">Bachelor of Science</a> degree in <a href="aeronautical%20engineering">aeronautical engineering</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Michigan">University of Michigan</a>, where he graduated first in his class in 1959.
After graduation, he went to <a href="Edwards%20Air%20Force%20Base">Edwards Air Force Base</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, as a student test pilot in June 1959. He remained there with the <a href="Air%20Force%20Test%20Center">Air Force Flight Test Center</a> as an experimental flight <a href="test%20pilot">test pilot</a>, completed the <a href="U.S.%20Air%20Force%20Test%20Pilot%20School">Air Force Experimental Flight Test Pilot School</a> (Class 59C) and <a href="Aerospace%20Research%20Pilot%20School">Aerospace Research Pilot School</a> (Class I), and joined the Manned Spacecraft Operations Branch in July 1962.
By September, McDivitt had logged over 2,500 flight hours, of which more than 2,000 hours was in <a href="jet%20aircraft">jet aircraft</a>. This included flying as a <a href="Chase%20plane">chase pilot</a> for <a href="Robert%20M.%20White">Robert M. White</a>'s <a href="North%20American%20X-15">North American X-15</a> flight on July 17, 1962, in which White reached an altitude of and became the first X-15 pilot to be awarded <a href="Astronaut%20Wings">Astronaut Wings</a> based on the USAF <a href="K%C3%A1rm%C3%A1n%20line">definition of space</a> as starting at . McDivitt was in line to fly the X-15 when White left, and to head the project office for testing the <a href="McDonnell%20Douglas%20F-4%20Phantom%20II">McDonnell F-4 Phantom II</a>, but he heard that <a href="NASA">NASA</a> was looking to select a second group of astronauts to augment the <a href="Mercury%20Seven">Mercury Seven</a>, and, after some thought, he decided to apply.
NASA career.
Project Gemini.
McDivitt was selected as an astronaut by NASA in September 1962 as part of <a href="Astronaut%20Group%202">Astronaut Group 2</a>. On July 29, 1964, it was announced that he had been chosen as command pilot of <a href="Gemini%204">Gemini 4</a>, becoming the first U.S. astronaut to command a crew on his first spaceflight. Only two other <a href="Project%20Gemini">Gemini</a> astronauts from this group commanded their first flights: <a href="Frank%20Borman">Frank Borman</a> (<a href="Gemini%207">Gemini 7</a>) and <a href="Neil%20Armstrong">Neil Armstrong</a> (<a href="Gemini%208">Gemini 8</a>). The <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20Astronaut%20Office">Chief of the Astronaut Office</a>, Mercury Seven astronaut <a href="Deke%20Slayton">Deke Slayton</a>, selected <a href="Ed%20White%20%28astronaut%29">Ed White</a> as his pilot because the two men knew each other well, having attended the University of Michigan and test pilot school together.
The mission objectives were ill-defined at first, but consideration was given to performing <a href="extravehicular%20activity">extravehicular activity</a> (EVA), <a href="space%20rendezvous">space rendezvous</a> and <a href="orbital%20station-keeping">orbital station-keeping</a>. Knowing that EVA (sometimes called a "spacewalk") was a possibility, McDivitt pressed for it to be included in the mission. As a result, NASA management agreed to ensure that the <a href="Gemini%20space%20suit">Gemini space suit</a> for the mission was capable of being used for EVA. <a href="Kenneth%20S.%20Kleinknecht">Kenneth S. Kleinknecht</a> told the July 1964 press conference that announced the mission that one of the crew might open the hatch and stick his head outside, but this attracted little attention. On March 18, 1965, <a href="cosmonaut">cosmonaut</a> <a href="Alexei%20Leonov">Alexei Leonov</a> became the first man to perform an EVA, on the <a href="Voskhod%202">Voskhod 2</a> mission, but not until May 25 was EVA approved for Gemini 4 by <a href="List%20of%20administrators%20and%20deputy%20administrators%20of%20NASA">NASA administrator</a> <a href="James%20E.%20Webb">James E. Webb</a>. 
Gemini 4 was launched on June 3, 1965. The mission lasted 97 hours and 56 minutes, and made 62 orbits, The first objective was to attempt the first space rendezvous with the spacecraft's spent <a href="Titan%20II%20GLV">Titan II</a> <a href="launch%20vehicle">launch vehicle</a>'s upper stage. This was not successful; McDivitt was unable to get closer than what he estimated to be . Several factors worked against him. There were depth-perception problems (his and White's visual estimates of the distance differed, variously longer or shorter than each other at different times). The <a href="orbital%20mechanics">orbital mechanics</a> of rendezvous were not yet well understood by NASA engineers or astronauts; catching up to something requires slowing down. Also, the stage was venting its remaining propellant, which kept pushing it around in different directions relative to the spacecraft.
McDivitt finally broke off the rendezvous attempt in order to save propellant and preserve the second objective, which was for White to perform the first United States EVA. McDivitt controlled the capsule's attitude and photographed White during the "walk". The hatch on Gemini 4, through which White exited to make his walk, was prone to problems with the latch mechanism gears coming unmeshed, making it difficult to open and re-latch the hatch. McDivitt had spent some time before the flight with a <a href="McDonnell">McDonnell</a> engineer, improvising a technique of forcing the gears to mesh by inserting the fingers inside the mechanism. The hatch was difficult to open and also to relatch during the flight, but McDivitt was able to get it working both times, with his hands in his pressurized space suit gloves. If he had not been able to get the hatch latched after the spacewalk, both men would have most likely not survived re-entry.
On the second day, over Hawaii, while White was asleep, McDivitt happened to see an <a href="unidentified%20flying%20object">unidentified flying object</a> (UFO), which he described as looking "like a beer can or a pop can, and with a little thing like maybe like a pencil or something sticking out of it". He took a few photographs of it, but did not have time to properly set exposure or focus properly. He believes that since it was visible to him, it must have been in an orbit close to that of his spacecraft, probably a piece of ice or <a href="multi-layer%20insulation">multi-layer insulation</a> that had broken off. Word of the "UFO photos" reached the press by the time the flight splashed down, and one eager reporter waited for the Gemini 4 photos to be processed. He found one with a cluster of three or four images that looked like disc-shaped objects with tails, which became known as the "tadpole" photo. McDivitt has identified these as reflections of bolts in the multipaned windows. Mercury Seven astronaut <a href="Gordon%20Cooper">Gordon Cooper</a> wrote in his memoirs that it is the only officially reported account of a UFO in any of the Mercury, Gemini or Apollo missions.
The mission ran into trouble in its final stages when there was a computer failure. Deviating from the flight plan, <a href="flight%20controller">flight controller</a> <a href="Chris%20Kraft">Chris Kraft</a> ordered McDivitt to perform a rolling <a href="atmospheric%20entry">atmospheric entry</a> like the Mercury astronauts had used rather than the lifting bank angle entry that the computer had been intended to help them achieve. On the way down, McDivitt struggled with a stuck thruster, but eventually slowed and ultimately halted the roll rate. The spacecraft overshot its landing point by , but the astronauts were soon reached by the recovery ship, the . The astronauts found that they were now celebrities. President <a href="Lyndon%20B.%20Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> came to <a href="Houston">Houston</a> to congratulate them, and he promoted them to the rank of <a href="lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>.
 Later that week they traveled to the <a href="White%20House">White House</a> where Johnson presented them the <a href="NASA%20Exceptional%20Service%20Medal">NASA Exceptional Service Medal</a>. They were given a <a href="ticker%20tape%20parade">ticker tape parade</a> in Chicago, and went to the 1965 <a href="Paris%20Air%20Show">Paris Air Show</a>, where they met cosmonaut <a href="Yuri%20Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>.
Project Apollo.
On March 21, 1966, NASA announced that McDivitt would be the <a href="Astronaut%20ranks%20and%20positions">commander</a> (CDR) of the backup crew of the first crewed <a href="Project%20Apollo">Project Apollo</a> mission, known as AS-204. The other members of his crew were <a href="Astronaut%20Group%203">Astronaut Group 3</a> astronauts <a href="David%20Scott">David Scott</a> and <a href="Rusty%20Schweickart">Rusty Schweickart</a>. The prime crew was commanded by Mercury Seven astronaut <a href="Gus%20Grissom">Gus Grissom</a>, with Ed White and rookie Group 3 astronaut <a href="Roger%20Chaffee">Roger Chaffee</a>. Their mission was to test the <a href="Apollo%20command%20and%20service%20module">Apollo command and service module</a> (CSM) in Earth orbit. By December 1966, hopes that the Apollo spacecraft would be ready to fly in 1966 were fading fast, and NASA announced on December 22 that they were replaced as backups for AS-204 by <a href="Wally%20Schirra">Wally Schirra</a>, <a href="Donn%20Eisele">Donn Eisele</a>, and <a href="Walt%20Cunningham">Walt Cunningham</a>, the crew of the original second mission, which was cancelled. McDivitt's crew became the prime crew of a new second mission flying both the CSM and the <a href="lunar%20module">lunar module</a> (LM). The <a href="Saturn%20V">Saturn V</a> rocket was not expected to be available, so the mission would be flown with two <a href="Saturn%20IB">Saturn IB</a> rockets, one for the CSM and one for the LM. This mission was called AS-205/208. Under the revised schedule, AS-204 would be flown in February 1967, followed by AS-205/208 in August. It was hoped that the Saturn V would be available by the end of the year, and it would be flown as a third mission with Borman as CDR and Group 3 astronauts <a href="Michael%20Collins%20%28astronaut%29">Michael Collins</a> and <a href="Bill%20Anders">Bill Anders</a>.
McDivitt and his crew were training for this mission when disaster struck on January 27, 1967: <a href="Apollo%201">a cabin fire</a> killed Grissom's crew. All crew assignments were canceled. During the <a href="United%20States%20Congress">Congressional</a> hearings that followed, McDivitt expressed confidence in NASA's management and safety measures. After the Apollo 1 fire, plans resumed for McDivitt's crew to fly the Lunar Module mission as the second crewed flight. This was officially announced on November 20, 1967. By the summer of 1968, it was expected that the mission would now be flown as Apollo 8 in December with the Saturn V, which was now expected to be available, but it was increasingly clear that the lunar module would not ready by that time. McDivitt was summoned to Slayton's office. According to McDivitt:
Apollo 9, McDivitt's ten-day Earth orbital Lunar module test mission, lifted off on March 3, 1969. Because there were two spacecraft, two names were required. McDivitt's crew called their lunar module "Spider" and the command module "Gumdrop". The crew's first major orbital task was to separate the CSM from the <a href="S-IVB">S-IVB</a> upper stage, turn around and then dock with the LM, which was on the end of the S-IVB, after which the combined spacecraft separated from the rocket. Scott docked the CSM with the LM, and the <a href="probe-and-drogue">probe-and-drogue</a> docking assembly worked properly. After McDivitt and Schweickart inspected the tunnel connecting the CSM and LM, the assembled spacecraft separated from the S-IVB. The next task was to demonstrate that two docked spacecraft could be maneuvered with the one engine, the <a href="Service%20Propulsion%20System">Service Propulsion System</a> (SPS). This was also successfully accomplished. The S-IVB was then fired again to send it into solar orbit.
The next day McDivitt and Schweickart donned their space suits and entered the LM. This was the first time that astronauts had transferred from one spacecraft to another. They then tested the LM's propulsion systems. On the fourth day, Schweickart donned the <a href="Primary%20Life%20Support%20System">Primary Life Support System</a>, the backpack that astronauts would later wear on lunar surface EVAs, and exited the LM. At the same time, Scott opened the door of the CSM, and the two astronauts took pictures of each other. The next day, Scott undocked, and McDivitt flew the LM, putting the spacecraft's descent engine through its paces. As with the CSM, the crew quickly gained confidence in the reliability and performance of their spacecraft. Finally, he used the LM's ascent engine to dock with the CSM once again. After 10 days during which it had made 151 orbits, Apollo 9 splashed safely down in the Atlantic, where it was retrieved by the .
After Apollo 9, McDivitt became Manager of Lunar Landing Operations in May 1969, and led a team that planned the lunar exploration program and redesigned the spacecraft to accomplish this task. In August 1969, he became Manager of the Apollo Spacecraft Program. As such, he was the program manager for <a href="Apollo%2012">Apollo 12</a>, <a href="Apollo%2013">13</a>, <a href="Apollo%2014">14</a>, <a href="Apollo%2015">15</a> and <a href="Apollo%2016">16</a> missions. He was promoted to the rank of <a href="brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> on February 17, 1972. When the selection of <a href="Gene%20Cernan">Gene Cernan</a> to command the <a href="Apollo%2017">Apollo 17</a> mission was announced, McDivitt confronted Kraft over not being consulted about it, and threatened to resign unless Cernan was removed. Kraft consulted with Slayton, who gave a less than frank account of a January 1971 helicopter accident that Cernan had been involved in. Kraft then informed McDivitt that Cernan's selection stood, and McDivitt resigned, although he stayed on until the end of the Apollo 16 mission.
Post-NASA career.
McDivitt retired from the USAF and left NASA in June 1972, to take the position of Executive <a href="Vice%20President">Vice President</a>, Corporate Affairs for <a href="Consumers%20Power%20Company">Consumers Power Company</a>. In March 1975, he joined <a href="Pullman%20Company">Pullman, Inc.</a> as Executive Vice President and a <a href="Director%20%28business%29">director</a>. In October 1975 he became <a href="President%20%28corporate%20title%29">President</a> of the Pullman Standard Division.
In January 1981 he joined <a href="Rockwell%20International">Rockwell International</a> where he was the Senior Vice President, Government Operations and International at the time of his retirement, <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> He retired in 1995.
Organizations.
McDivitt is a member of the <a href="Society%20of%20Experimental%20Test%20Pilots">Society of Experimental Test Pilots</a>, the <a href="American%20Institute%20of%20Aeronautics%20and%20Astronautics">American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics</a>, <a href="Tau%20Beta%20Pi">Tau Beta Pi</a>, <a href="Phi%20Kappa%20Phi">Phi Kappa Phi</a>, Atlantic Council on Foreign Diplomacy, and Advisory Council-University of Michigan. He is also a <a href="Knight%20of%20Columbus">Knight of Columbus</a>, and represented the Order at the <a href="Third%20World%20Congress%20for%20the%20Lay%20Apostolate">Third World Congress for the Lay Apostolate</a> at the <a href="Vatican%20City">Vatican</a> in 1967.
Awards and honors.
McDivitt's received an <a href="Honorary%20degree">honorary doctorate</a> degrees in astronautical science by the University of Michigan in 1965, and honorary <a href="Doctor%20of%20Science%20degree">Doctor of Science degree</a> from <a href="Seton%20Hall%20University">Seton Hall University</a> in 1969, an Honorary Doctor of Science from <a href="Miami%20University">Miami University</a> (Ohio) in 1970, and an Honorary <a href="Doctor%20of%20Law">Doctor of Law degree</a> from <a href="Eastern%20Michigan%20University">Eastern Michigan University</a> in 1975.
McDivitt was one of ten Gemini astronauts inducted into the <a href="New%20Mexico%20Museum%20of%20Space%20History">International Space Hall of Fame</a> in 1982. McDivitt, along with the other 12 Gemini astronauts, was inducted into the second <a href="U.S.%20Astronaut%20Hall%20of%20Fame">U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame</a> class in 1993.
In media.
In the 1998 <a href="HBO">HBO</a> <a href="miniseries">miniseries</a> "<a href="From%20the%20Earth%20to%20the%20Moon%20%28miniseries%29">From the Earth to the Moon</a>" McDivitt was played by <a href="Conor%20O%27Farrell">Conor O'Farrell</a>.
McDivitt appeared as himself on "<a href="The%20Brady%20Bunch">The Brady Bunch</a>" in a 1974 fifth-season episode about UFOs, "Out of This World", as a guest on a talk show to talk about his UFO experience. At the end of the talk show McDivitt signed autographs for the characters <a href="Peter%20Brady%20%28The%20Brady%20Bunch%29">Peter Brady</a> and <a href="Bobby%20Brady">Bobby Brady</a>.
Private life.
McDivitt married Patricia Ann Haas in 1956. They had four children: Michael, Ann Lynn, Patrick, and Kathleen. They later divorced, and he married Judith Ann Odell in 1985, and from this marriage he gained two stepchildren. His recreational interests include <a href="hunting">hunting</a>, <a href="fishing">fishing</a>, <a href="golf">golf</a>, <a href="water%20sports">water sports</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a>, and all <a href="outdoor%20activities">outdoor activities</a>.
